Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll solve this problem step by step using tidyverse functions.

First, I need to:
1. Group flights by tailnum
2. Count total flights and NA arr_delays per tailnum
3. Calculate the proportion of NA arr_delays
4. Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
5. Find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NAs

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate the total flights and NA count
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter for planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NAs in descending order
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code will return the tailnum of the aircraft that has at least 100 flights and the highest proportion of missing arrival delay values.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

Here's how I'll solve this:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each plane
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_arr_delay = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to only include planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Arrange in descending order of NA proportion
  arrange(desc(prop_na_arr_delay)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by tailnum
2. Calculates for each tailnum:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arr_delay values
   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay values
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Orders by the proportion of NA values in descending order
5. Takes the top result (the tailnum with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum value

input.content:
I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among those that have flown at least 100 flights.

Here's how I'll solve this:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each plane
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na_arr_delay = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to only include planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Arrange in descending order of NA proportion
  arrange(desc(prop_na_arr_delay)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights by tailnum
2. Calculates for each tailnum:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arr_delay values
   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay values
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Orders by the proportion of NA values in descending order
5. Takes the top result (the tailnum with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum value

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

content.text:
I'll solve this step by step:

1. First, I'll join the flights and planes data to work with both datasets
2. Then, I'll group by `tailnum` and calculate:
   - Total number of flights for each tailnum
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay
   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay
3. Finally, I'll filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights and find the one with the highest NA proportion

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum to count flights per plane
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to only planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NAs in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

input.content:
I'll solve this step by step:

1. First, I'll join the flights and planes data to work with both datasets
2. Then, I'll group by `tailnum` and calculate:
   - Total number of flights for each tailnum
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay
   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay
3. Finally, I'll filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights and find the one with the highest NA proportion

Here's the code:

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum to count flights per plane
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to only planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by proportion of NAs in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Get the tailnum with highest proportion
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code will identify the plane (by tailnum) that has the highest proportion of missing arrival delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 times.

   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay
3. Finally, I'll filter for tailnums with at least 100 flights and find the one with the highest NA proportion

Here's the code:

```r

  # Group by tailnum to count flights per plane
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
```

content.text:
# Error with `.by` in `mutate()`

This error occurs when you're trying to use `.by` inside `mutate()` incorrectly. The error message indicates that your `by` argument contains too many values (5818984) when it should match your data frame's row count (2909492) or be length 1.

## Common causes and solutions:

1. **Incorrect syntax** - `.by` should be a separate argument to `mutate()`, not inside the mutating expressions:

   ```r
   # INCORRECT 
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), by = c(id, date))
   
   # CORRECT 
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   ```

2. **Variables not quoted** - When using `.by`, variable names should not have quotes:

   ```r
   # CORRECT 
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   ```

3. **Using vectors instead of column references** - Make sure you're referring to column names, not creating vectors:

   ```r
   # INCORRECT (if id and date are vectors in environment) 
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   
   # CORRECT 
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c("id", "date"))
   ```

If you can share more of your code, I can provide a more specific solution.

# Error with `.by` in `mutate()`: Understanding the Issue

This error occurs when using the `.by` parameter incorrectly in `mutate()`. The error message indicates that your `by` argument contains twice as many rows as expected (5818984 vs 2909492).

## Likely Causes

1. **Incorrect Parameter Name**: You're using `by = c(id, date)` instead of `.by = c(id, date)`
2. **Double Column Reference**: You're referring to columns that are being duplicated

## Solutions

### Option 1: Use `.by` not `by`
```r
# INCORRECT
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), by = c(id, date))

# CORRECT
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), .by = c(id, date))
```

### Option 2: Use proper column notation
```r
# If using unquoted column names, use this:
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), .by = c(id, date))

# If you need quoted column names:
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), .by = c("id", "date"))
```

### Option 3: If you're using dplyr < 1.1.0
Older versions don't support `.by`. Use `group_by()` and `ungroup()` instead:

```r
df %>% 
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_var = some_calculation()) %>%
  ungroup()
```

content.text:
# Error with `.by` in `mutate()`: Understanding the Issue

This error occurs when using the `.by` parameter incorrectly in `mutate()`. The error message indicates that your `by` argument contains twice as many rows as expected (5818984 vs 2909492).

## Likely Causes

1. **Incorrect Parameter Name**: You're using `by = c(id, date)` instead of `.by = c(id, date)`
2. **Double Column Reference**: You're referring to columns that are being duplicated

## Solutions

### Option 1: Use `.by` not `by`
```r
# INCORRECT
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), by = c(id, date))

# CORRECT
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), .by = c(id, date))
```

### Option 2: Use proper column notation
```r
# If using unquoted column names, use this:
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), .by = c(id, date))

# If you need quoted column names:
df %>% mutate(new_var = some_calculation(), .by = c("id", "date"))
```

### Option 3: If you're using dplyr < 1.1.0
Older versions don't support `.by`. Use `group_by()` and `ungroup()` instead:

```r
df %>% 
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_var = some_calculation()) %>%
  ungroup()
```

content.text:
# Error with `.by` in `mutate()`

The error you're experiencing with `.by` inside `mutate()` suggests you're having a syntax issue. When using the `.by` parameter in dplyr functions (including `mutate()`), the correct syntax is different from how you're using it.

## The Fix

Instead of:
```r
mutate(by = c(id, date))
```

Use one of these correct approaches:

### Option 1: Using `.by` parameter
```r
mutate(...your calculations..., .by = c("id", "date"))
```
or
```r
mutate(...your calculations..., .by = c(id, date))
```

### Option 2: Using `group_by()` first
```r
data %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(...your calculations...) %>%
  ungroup()
```

## What Went Wrong

The error message indicates that `by` was being treated as a new column you were trying to create (rather than as the grouping parameter), and it was creating a vector with twice the length of your data.

Remember that `.by` is a parameter to the `mutate()` function, so it should come after your column calculations, not as one of the columns you're creating.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

    structure(

      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.

```
task_create <- function(
```

Here's how to modify the `task_create` function to add a `name` argument that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

This implementation:

1. Adds a `name` parameter that comes after `dataset` in the parameter list
2. Uses `deparse(substitute(dataset))` as the default value, which captures the variable name used when calling the function
3. Adds the name as an attribute to the result using `attr(res, "name") <- name`

With this modification, when you call `x <- task_create(dataset = eval)`, the attribute `attr(x, "name")` will be "eval".

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points in ggplot2 only along the x-axis while preserving the original y values, you can use one of the following approaches:

## Option 1: Use `geom_jitter()` with width and height parameters

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

The key parameters are:
- `width = 0.2` controls the amount of horizontal jittering (adjust as needed)
- `height = 0` disables any vertical jittering

## Option 2: Use `position_jitter()` with explicit parameters

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

## Option 3: Create a custom position adjustment

If you need even more control, you can manually add jitter:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable + runif(n(), -0.1, 0.1), y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point()
```

This adds random noise between -0.1 and 0.1 to your x values only.

Choose the approach that works best for your specific visualization needs!

content.text:
# Jittering Points Horizontally in ggplot2

To jitter points only horizontally (along the x-axis) while keeping the y values unchanged in ggplot2, you can use `geom_jitter()` with specific width and height parameters:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0)
```

The key here is setting:
- `width = 0.1` (or any value you prefer for the amount of horizontal jitter)
- `height = 0` (to prevent any vertical jittering)

## Alternative Method

You can also use `position_jitter()` for more control:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0))
```

## Example with Sample Data

Here's a complete example:

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30)
)

# Plot with horizontal jitter only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Points jittered only horizontally")
```

Adjust the `width` parameter to control how much horizontal spread you want for your points.

# Jittering Points Horizontally in ggplot2

To jitter points only horizontally (along the x-axis) while keeping the y values unchanged in ggplot2, you can use `geom_jitter()` with specific width and height parameters:

```r

  geom_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0)
```

- `height = 0` (to prevent any vertical jittering)

```r
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0))
```

```r
  labs(title = "Points jittered only horizontally")
```

Adjust the `width` parameter to control how much horizontal spread you want for your points.

# Jittering Points in ggplot2 on X-Axis Only

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2 while keeping the y values unchanged, you can use `geom_jitter()` with specific width and height parameters:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

The key is setting:
- `width` to a positive value (e.g., 0.2) to control the amount of horizontal jittering
- `height = 0` to prevent any vertical jittering

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

This gives you more flexibility if you need to apply the same jittering to multiple geoms or want to customize the jitter further.

I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

content.text:
# Fixing Name Substitution in Your Function

The issue is happening because when you pass `dataset = simple_addition`, R is evaluating `simple_addition` to its value before substituting it in the function. By the time `deparse(substitute(dataset))` runs, `dataset` holds the actual data, not the variable name.

## Solution

You need to capture the variable name *before* it's evaluated. Here are two approaches:

### Option 1: Use NSE (Non-Standard Evaluation) with a custom interface

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Get the calling expression
    call <- match.call()
    
    # If name is NULL, use the dataset argument name
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(call$dataset)
    }
    
    # Rest of your function...
}
```

### Option 2: More explicit approach with a dedicated argument capture

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Get the calling expression
    mc <- match.call()
    
    # If name is NULL, extract the dataset argument name
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- as.character(mc$dataset)
    }
    
    # Rest of your function...
}
```

With either approach, when you call `task_create(dataset = simple_addition)`, the `name` parameter will be "simple_addition" as desired.

The key is using `match.call()` which gives you the actual call that was used to invoke the function, with arguments unevaluated, so you can extract the original variable name.

model_graded_qa(partial_credit = TRUE).explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission adequately addresses the criterion that the `name` default is evaluated lazily and must be evaluated early in the function.

Looking at the submission, it doesn't correctly identify the core issue. The problem isn't about capturing the unevaluated expression - the `deparse(substitute(dataset))` approach is actually correct for this purpose. The real issue is that `name` is being defined with a default value that depends on `dataset`, but this default is evaluated lazily (only when `name` is actually used in the function).

By the time `name` is evaluated internally, `dataset` has already been evaluated and contains the full data structure rather than the variable name. This is why the name becomes the deparsed data structure instead of "simple_addition".

The submission proposes using `match.call()` which is one possible approach, but doesn't address the core issue highlighted in the criterion - that `name` needs to be evaluated early in the function. The solution should include something like `force(name)` at the beginning of the function to ensure the default is evaluated before `dataset` is used elsewhere.

None of the solutions in the submission explicitly forces early evaluation of `name`, which is the key point in the criterion.

GRADE: I

[Submission]: # Fixing Substitute for Task Names

The issue is how `deparse(substitute(dataset))` works when the argument is already evaluated before being passed to your function. In your example, `dataset = simple_addition` is passing the actual data frame/tibble, not the symbol name.

## Solution Options

### Option 1: Pass the Name Explicitly

The simplest solution is to ask users to pass the name explicitly when needed:

```r
tsk <- task_create(
  dataset = simple_addition,
  name = "simple_addition"
)
```

### Option 2: Use Non-Standard Evaluation

For automatic name capture, you need to modify your function to use non-standard evaluation:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Capture the expression used for dataset
  dataset_expr <- substitute(dataset)
  
  # If name is NULL, use the expression as the name
  if (is.null(name)) {
    # Handle different types of expressions
    if (is.symbol(dataset_expr)) {
      name <- as.character(dataset_expr)
    } else {
      # For complex expressions, use a default name
      name <- "unnamed_task"
    }
  }
  
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

### Option 3: Use rlang for Cleaner NSE

For a more robust approach, use rlang's quosure system:

```r
library(rlang)

task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  dataset_quo <- enquo(dataset)
  
  if (is.null(name)) {
    dataset_expr <- quo_get_expr(dataset_quo)
    if (is.symbol(dataset_expr)) {
      name <- as.character(dataset_expr)
    } else {
      name <- "unnamed_task"
    }
  }
  
  # Rest of your function...
}
```

## Why Your Current Code Doesn't Work

Your code executes `deparse(substitute(dataset))` *after* `dataset` has already been evaluated. So `substitute(dataset)` returns the actual tibble object, and when `deparse()` is applied to that, you get the printed representation of the entire data structure.

The solutions above capture the expression *before* evaluation occurs, which gives you access to the symbol name.

content.text:
# Getting the Variable Name in Your Function

The issue with your code is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` is evaluating the value of `dataset` rather than getting the symbol (variable name) used to call the function.

## Solution

To get the actual variable name that was passed to your function, you need to capture it before it's evaluated. Here's how to fix your function:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,  # Make name NULL by default
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # If name is not provided, try to get the variable name
    if(is.null(name)) {
        name_expr <- substitute(dataset)
        if(is.name(name_expr)) {
            name <- as.character(name_expr)
        } else {
            # Fallback for when the argument is an expression, not a simple variable
            name <- "unnamed_task"
        }
    }
    
    # Rest of your function...
}
```

## Explanation

This approach:

1. Takes `name` as NULL by default
2. Uses `substitute(dataset)` to capture the unevaluated expression
3. Checks if that expression is a simple name (variable) with `is.name()`
4. If it is a name, converts it to a character string
5. If not (e.g., if an inline calculation or complex expression was provided), uses a fallback name

With this approach, when you call `task_create(simple_addition)`, the name will be "simple_addition" as expected.

## Alternative Approach

If you prefer to keep the original parameter style, you could use non-standard evaluation:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Clean up the name if it's a complex expression
    if(grepl("^structure\\(", name)) {
        name <- "unnamed_task"
    }
    
    # Rest of your function...
}
```

This approach is simpler but less robust, as it only handles the specific case where the deparsed expression starts with "structure(".

model_graded_qa(partial_credit = TRUE).explanation:
I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly addresses the issue described in the criterion: replacing `NS(id)` with `session$ns` in the module server to maintain proper namespace hierarchies.

Looking at the submitted answer, the key fix proposed is indeed changing:
```r
innerServer <- function(id){
  moduleServer(id, function(input, output, session) {
    ns <- NS(id)
```

to:
```r
innerServer <- function(id){
  moduleServer(id, function(input, output, session) {
    ns <- session$ns
```

The answer correctly identifies that the issue is a namespace problem where using `NS(id)` inside a module server creates a new namespace that doesn't maintain the proper hierarchy, which causes the dynamically generated UI elements to be double-namespaced. This makes them unable to connect with their corresponding server outputs.

The solution explains that `session$ns` should be used instead because it automatically handles the correct namespacing, preserving the hierarchical relationship with parent modules.

The submission also includes a complete fixed code example that implements this change, and explains the rationale behind the fix, which matches exactly what the criterion describes as the solution.

GRADE: C

content.text:
# Error in pkgdown.yaml Workflow with Remote Dependencies

This error occurs because the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow is having trouble resolving your remote dependency. The issue stems from how you've specified the dependency in your DESCRIPTION file versus how the repository is named.

## The Problem

The workflow is trying to install `spatialstuff` as specified in your `Imports:` section, but it can't find a package with that exact name. Despite having the `Remotes:` section pointing to the correct GitHub repository, the connection between these two specifications isn't being properly resolved.

## Solution

The issue is likely due to one of these reasons:

1. **Package name mismatch**: The actual package name in the remote repository's DESCRIPTION file might not match `spatialstuff`

2. **Remote specification format**: The format in your Remotes section needs to be more specific about the package name

Try this modification in your DESCRIPTION file:

```
Imports:
  spatialstuff
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
```

This explicitly links the package name in `Imports` with the GitHub repository in `Remotes`.

If the actual package in the GitHub repository has a different name in its DESCRIPTION file (for example, if it's actually called `spatial.stuff` internally), then you need to:

1. Change your `Imports` to match that name
2. Make the `Remotes` entry match accordingly

## Alternative Approaches

If the above doesn't work, you might:

1. **Use a different dependency resolution tool** in your workflow (like `remotes` instead of `pak`)

2. **Pre-install the dependency** explicitly in your GitHub Action before running pkgdown

3. **Check if there's a typo** in either your package name or the repository reference

Let me know if you need further assistance adjusting your configuration!

content.text:
# Issue with R Package Dependencies in pkgdown Workflow

It looks like you're encountering a common issue when dealing with GitHub-hosted dependencies in R packages, particularly when the package name differs from the repository name.

## The Problem

Your package depends on `spatialstuff`, but this package exists only in a GitHub repository named `org/spatial-Stuff`. The pkgdown workflow is failing because it can't find the package `spatialstuff` in the standard repositories.

## Why This Is Happening

The error occurs because:

1. The `Imports` field uses the R package name (`spatialstuff`)
2. The `Remotes` field correctly points to the GitHub repository (`org/spatial-Stuff`)
3. However, the pkgdown GitHub Action is not correctly resolving this connection

## Solution

You need to modify your `Remotes` field to explicitly specify the package name. Try changing your DESCRIPTION to:

```
Imports:
  spatialstuff
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
```

This syntax tells R package managers (including pak, which is used by the pkgdown workflow) that the package named `spatialstuff` should be installed from the GitHub repository `org/spatial-Stuff`.

## Alternative Solution

If the above doesn't work, you could also try specifying the full GitHub URL format:

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=github::org/spatial-Stuff
```

## Additional Notes

1. Make sure the package inside `org/spatial-Stuff` is actually named `spatialstuff` in its own DESCRIPTION file
2. If you're using a specific branch or tag, you can add that like: `spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff@main`
3. You might need to update your GitHub Action workflow to ensure it has the right permissions to access private repositories if applicable

This is a normal issue with R packages that depend on GitHub-hosted packages, especially when there's a mismatch between the R package name and the repository name.

content.text:
# Analysis of Package Dependency Error

The error you're encountering with your pkgdown GitHub workflow is due to a mismatch between the package name in your Imports section and how the package is actually named in its repository or DESCRIPTION file.

## The Issue

The problem is that:

1. Your package's DESCRIPTION indicates it imports `spatialstuff`
2. You're using `org/spatial-Stuff` as the remote location
3. The package building system (pak) cannot resolve this dependency

## Why This Is Happening

This issue occurs because the package name in the GitHub repository (which is likely defined in its own DESCRIPTION file) doesn't match what you're importing. 

When you specify a remote like `org/spatial-Stuff`, the system expects the actual package name (as defined in that package's DESCRIPTION file) to match what you've listed in your Imports section.

## Solutions

1. **Check the actual package name**: First, verify what the actual package name is in the `spatial-Stuff` repository's DESCRIPTION file. GitHub repository names and R package names don't have to be identical.

2. **Correct approach**: If the package's name in its DESCRIPTION is actually `spatialstuff`, then your setup is correct and the issue might be elsewhere.

3. **If names differ**: If the actual package name (in its DESCRIPTION) is different from `spatialstuff`, update your Imports section to match the real package name.

4. **Use package name aliases**: If you need the specific version from GitHub but with a different name, you can use:
   ```
   Remotes:
    org/spatial-Stuff@*release
   ```
   or
   ```
   Remotes:
    spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff
   ```

## Notes

The error is coming from the `pak` package which is used by the GitHub Actions workflow for pkgdown. It's trying to resolve and install all dependencies before building your documentation.

This is most likely not a GitHub Actions issue but a package naming/reference issue that would also affect regular package installation.

[Task]: I see:

```
Error:
! promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems?
```

When evaluating the function returned by this function:

```
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?
***
[Submission]: The error you're encountering is due to recursive evaluation of the default arguments. When you set a default value in a function argument that uses another function, R tries to evaluate that function immediately. In your case, `chat = ellmer::chat_claude()` is creating a recursive reference issue.

Here's how to fix it:

```r
generate <- function(chat = NULL) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    # If chat is NULL, initialize it here
    if (is.null(chat)) {
      chat <- ellmer::chat_claude()
    }
    
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

What this fix does:

1. Sets the default value of the outer `chat` parameter to `NULL` instead of calling `ellmer::chat_claude()` immediately
2. Inside the inner function, checks if `chat` is `NULL` and only then calls `ellmer::chat_claude()`

This approach avoids the recursive evaluation problem because the default value is now a simple `NULL` rather than a function call that might lead to circular references.

Alternatively, you could use the `force()` function to evaluate the chat parameter immediately:

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  force(chat)  # Evaluate chat immediately
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

Either approach should resolve the recursive default argument reference error.

[Criterion]: It can be fixed by changing the name of the `chat` argument in one of the functions or assigning the `chat` object in the outer function to a different variable name internally and then supplying that renamed object as the default to the inner function.

content.text:
This error occurs because of a recursive reference in your default arguments. When you have a parameter named `chat` in both the outer and inner functions with default values that refer to each other, it can create a loop.

Let's fix this by using different parameter names to avoid the recursion issue:

```r
generate <- function(default_chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = default_chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

In this corrected version:

1. I renamed the outer function's parameter to `default_chat` to avoid naming conflicts
2. The inner function's default value for `chat` now references this renamed parameter
3. This breaks the recursive reference chain that was causing the error

The problem was that R was getting confused about which `chat` was being referred to in the default argument, leading to an infinite evaluation cycle. Using distinct names for the parameters resolves this issue.

samples.input:
I see this warning and error when I launch my shiny app:

```
Listening on http://127.0.0.1:3516
Warning: Error in $: Can't read output 'plot'
  46: <Anonymous>
  45: signalCondition
  44: signal_abort
  43: rlang::abort
  42: $.shinyoutput
  40: server [#2]
   3: runApp
   2: print.shiny.appobj
   1: <Anonymous>
Error in output$plot : Can't read output 'plot'
```

Here's the app's code:

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
ckd_condition <- reactive({
  input$condition
})

visit_threshold <- reactive({
  input$visit_threshold
})

filtered_data <- reactive({
  Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
    filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition, VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold)
})

# Create a linear model and visualization
output$plot <- renderPlot({
  validate(
    need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
    need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
  )
                                 # Filter the data based on the user's input
  data <- filtered_data()
  
                                 # Create a linear model
  lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
  
                                 # Create a plot of the linear model
  ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
    geom_point() + 
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
    labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
})

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = function(input, output) {
  output$plot
})
```

How do I fix it?
samples.target:
There's a `output$plot` alone in the anonymous server function. The solution is to move the `output$plot` and rendering code into a proper server function, like:

```
# ...same ui

server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive functions to filter the data based on user input
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Create a linear model and visualization
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
                                   # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
                                   # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
                                   # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

content.text:
The error occurs because your server function is not properly set up. In a Shiny app, the server function needs to contain the code that defines reactive objects and outputs, but your code has these definitions outside the server function.

Here's how to fix your app:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Server function with reactive elements
server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive functions for filtering data
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Create the plot output
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

Key changes made:
1. Moved all reactive expressions inside the server function
2. Simplified the reactive code by directly using input values rather than creating separate reactive expressions for them
3. Made sure the server function properly defines the outputs
4. Fixed the call to shinyApp by passing the server function itself, not a function that just returns output$plot

This should resolve the "Can't read output 'plot'" error you're seeing.

```r
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Server function with reactive elements
server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive functions for filtering data
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Create the plot output
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

Key changes made:
1. Moved all reactive expressions inside the server function
2. Simplified the reactive code by directly using input values rather than creating separate reactive expressions for them
3. Made sure the server function properly defines the outputs
4. Fixed the call to shinyApp by passing the server function itself, not a function that just returns output$plot

This should resolve the "Can't read output 'plot'" error you're seeing.

content.text:
The error is occurring because your server function is not correctly defined. You're trying to access `output$plot` but it's not properly set up inside the server function. Here's how to fix your code:

```r
# Run the application
shinyApp(
  ui = ui, 
  server = function(input, output) {
    # Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
    ckd_condition <- reactive({
      input$condition
    })
    
    visit_threshold <- reactive({
      input$visit_threshold
    })
    
    filtered_data <- reactive({
      Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
        filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition(), VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold())
    })
    
    # Create a linear model and visualization
    output$plot <- renderPlot({
      validate(
        need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
        need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
      )
      
      # Filter the data based on the user's input
      data <- filtered_data()
      
      # Create a linear model
      lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
      
      # Create a plot of the linear model
      ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
        geom_point() + 
        geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
        labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
    })
  }
)
```

The key changes I made:

1. Moved all reactive functions and output definitions inside the server function.
2. Added parentheses `()` when calling reactive values: `ckd_condition()` and `visit_threshold()`.
3. Properly defined the `output$plot` inside the server function instead of just referencing it.

In Shiny applications, the server function is where you define all reactive logic and outputs. The way you had it structured, your reactive elements and output were defined outside the server function, which is why the error occurred.

input.content:
The error is occurring because your server function is not correctly defined. You're trying to access `output$plot` but it's not properly set up inside the server function. Here's how to fix your code:

```r
# Run the application
shinyApp(
  ui = ui, 
  server = function(input, output) {
    # Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
    ckd_condition <- reactive({
      input$condition
    })
    
    visit_threshold <- reactive({
      input$visit_threshold
    })
    
    filtered_data <- reactive({
      Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
        filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition(), VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold())
    })
    
    # Create a linear model and visualization
    output$plot <- renderPlot({
      validate(
        need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
        need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
      )
      
      # Filter the data based on the user's input
      data <- filtered_data()
      
      # Create a linear model
      lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
      
      # Create a plot of the linear model
      ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
        geom_point() + 
        geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
        labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
    })
  }
)
```

The key changes I made:

1. Moved all reactive functions and output definitions inside the server function.
2. Added parentheses `()` when calling reactive values: `ckd_condition()` and `visit_threshold()`.
3. Properly defined the `output$plot` inside the server function instead of just referencing it.

In Shiny applications, the server function is where you define all reactive logic and outputs. The way you had it structured, your reactive elements and output were defined outside the server function, which is why the error occurred.

content.text:
# Fixing your Shiny App Error

The error message `Can't read output 'plot'` is occurring because you have a fundamental issue in how you've structured your Shiny application. The main problem is that your server function is incomplete.

## The Issue

In your code, you've defined:
- The UI correctly
- The server function with just `output$plot`, but without actually running the rendering code

You've also defined the `output$plot` and several reactive expressions outside of the server function, which is incorrect. All server-side logic needs to be within the server function.

## How to Fix It

Here's the corrected version of your app:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create the UI
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Define the server logic
server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive expressions
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Render the plot
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

## Key Changes:

1. Moved all reactive expressions (`filtered_data`) inside the server function
2. Replaced the separate reactive expressions for `ckd_condition` and `visit_threshold` with direct references to `input$condition` and `input$visit_threshold`
3. Implemented the full server function properly, with all the rendering logic inside it
4. Defined the server function separately for clarity and then passed it to `shinyApp()`

This structure follows the standard Shiny application pattern and should resolve your error.

input.content:
# Fixing your Shiny App Error

The error message `Can't read output 'plot'` is occurring because you have a fundamental issue in how you've structured your Shiny application. The main problem is that your server function is incomplete.

## The Issue

In your code, you've defined:
- The UI correctly
- The server function with just `output$plot`, but without actually running the rendering code

You've also defined the `output$plot` and several reactive expressions outside of the server function, which is incorrect. All server-side logic needs to be within the server function.

## How to Fix It

Here's the corrected version of your app:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create the UI
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Define the server logic
server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive expressions
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Render the plot
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

## Key Changes:

1. Moved all reactive expressions (`filtered_data`) inside the server function
2. Replaced the separate reactive expressions for `ckd_condition` and `visit_threshold` with direct references to `input$condition` and `input$visit_threshold`
3. Implemented the full server function properly, with all the rendering logic inside it
4. Defined the server function separately for clarity and then passed it to `shinyApp()`

This structure follows the standard Shiny application pattern and should resolve your error.

# Fixing your Shiny App Error

The error message `Can't read output 'plot'` is occurring because you have a fundamental issue in how you've structured your Shiny application. The main problem is that your server function is incomplete.

## The Issue

In your code, you've defined:
- The UI correctly
- The server function with just `output$plot`, but without actually running the rendering code

You've also defined the `output$plot` and several reactive expressions outside of the server function, which is incorrect. All server-side logic needs to be within the server function.

## How to Fix It

Here's the corrected version of your app:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create the UI
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Define the server logic
server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive expressions
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Render the plot
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

## Key Changes:

1. Moved all reactive expressions (`filtered_data`) inside the server function
2. Replaced the separate reactive expressions for `ckd_condition` and `visit_threshold` with direct references to `input$condition` and `input$visit_threshold`
3. Implemented the full server function properly, with all the rendering logic inside it
4. Defined the server function separately for clarity and then passed it to `shinyApp()`

This structure follows the standard Shiny application pattern and should resolve your error.

samples.input:
Here's a GitHub issue:

<issue>
Google oauth now returns `refresh_token_expires_in` as one of the fields in its response. It looks like this change happened roughly yesterday morning (the warnings first appeared in my log at 5:09am CST, but it hadn't ran since 5:14pm the day before). Because of that, this line in `token_refresh() `now results in a warning (which really should be an error):

```
out$refresh_token <- out$refresh_token %||% refresh_token
# Warning message:
# In out$refresh_token :
#  partial match of 'refresh_token' to 'refresh_token_expires_in'
```

Since out has `refresh_token_expires_in` (and not `refresh_token`), adding `refresh_token` doesn't work as expected.

</issue>

Avoid partial matching of `refresh_token` in this function:

```r
token_refresh <- function(client, refresh_token, scope = NULL, token_params = list()) {
  out <- oauth_client_get_token(
    client,
    grant_type = "refresh_token",
    refresh_token = refresh_token,
    scope = scope,
    !!!token_params
  )
  out$refresh_token <- out$refresh_token %||% refresh_token
  out
}
```
samples.target: Change `out$refresh_token <- out$refresh_token %||% refresh_token` to `out[["refresh_token"]] <- out[["refresh_token"]] %||% refresh_token`. No other changes needed.

content.text:
Let me solve this issue. The problem is that R's partial matching feature is causing `out$refresh_token` to match with `out$refresh_token_expires_in` if there's no actual `refresh_token` field in the response.

Here's the fixed version of the function:

```r
token_refresh <- function(client, refresh_token, scope = NULL, token_params = list()) {
  out <- oauth_client_get_token(
    client,
    grant_type = "refresh_token",
    refresh_token = refresh_token,
    scope = scope,
    !!!token_params
  )
  # Use [[ instead of $ to avoid partial matching
  out[["refresh_token"]] <- out[["refresh_token"]] %||% refresh_token
  out
}
```

The key change is replacing `out$refresh_token` with `out[["refresh_token"]]`, which performs exact matching instead of partial matching. This ensures we're only accessing the exact field name "refresh_token" and not accidentally matching with "refresh_token_expires_in" or any other field that starts with "refresh_token".

Google oauth now returns `refresh_token_expires_in` as one of the fields in its response. It looks like this change happened roughly yesterday morning (the warnings first appeared in my log at 5:09am CST, but it hadn't ran since 5:14pm the day before). Because of that, this line in `token_refresh() `now results in a warning (which really should be an error):

```
out$refresh_token <- out$refresh_token %||% refresh_token
# Warning message:
# In out$refresh_token :
#  partial match of 'refresh_token' to 'refresh_token_expires_in'
```

Since out has `refresh_token_expires_in` (and not `refresh_token`), adding `refresh_token` doesn't work as expected.

</issue>

Avoid partial matching of `refresh_token` in this function:

```r
token_refresh <- function(client, refresh_token, scope = NULL, token_params = list()) {
  out <- oauth_client_get_token(
    client,
    grant_type = "refresh_token",
    refresh_token = refresh_token,
    scope = scope,
    !!!token_params
  )
  out$refresh_token <- out$refresh_token %||% refresh_token
  out
}
```
sample.target: Change `out$refresh_token <- out$refresh_token %||% refresh_token` to `out[["refresh_token"]] <- out[["refresh_token"]] %||% refresh_token`. No other changes needed.

Here's a GitHub issue:

<issue>
Google oauth now returns `refresh_token_expires_in` as one of the fields in its response. It looks like this change happened roughly yesterday morning (the warnings first appeared in my log at 5:09am CST, but it hadn't ran since 5:14pm the day before). Because of that, this line in `token_refresh() `now results in a warning (which really should be an error):

```

# Warning message:
# In out$refresh_token :
#  partial match of 'refresh_token' to 'refresh_token_expires_in'
```

Since out has `refresh_token_expires_in` (and not `refresh_token`), adding `refresh_token` doesn't work as expected.

</issue>

Avoid partial matching of `refresh_token` in this function:

```r
token_refresh <- function(client, refresh_token, scope = NULL, token_params = list()) {
  out <- oauth_client_get_token(
    client,
    grant_type = "refresh_token",
```

input.content:
The issue is that R is performing partial name matching, so when `out$refresh_token` is accessed and `out` doesn't have a `refresh_token` element but does have a `refresh_token_expires_in` element, R is using the partial match which causes the warning.

To fix this, we should use explicit access via `[[` which doesn't do partial matching:

```r
token_refresh <- function(client, refresh_token, scope = NULL, token_params = list()) {
  out <- oauth_client_get_token(
    client,
    grant_type = "refresh_token",
    refresh_token = refresh_token,
    scope = scope,
    !!!token_params
  )
  # Use [[ to avoid partial matching
  out$refresh_token <- out[["refresh_token"]] %||% refresh_token
  out
}
```

This change ensures we're explicitly checking for the exact name `refresh_token` without any partial matching behavior, resolving the warning that was occurring.

content.text:
The issue is that R is performing partial name matching, so when `out$refresh_token` is accessed and `out` doesn't have a `refresh_token` element but does have a `refresh_token_expires_in` element, R is using the partial match which causes the warning.

To fix this, we should use explicit access via `[[` which doesn't do partial matching:

```r
token_refresh <- function(client, refresh_token, scope = NULL, token_params = list()) {
  out <- oauth_client_get_token(
    client,
    grant_type = "refresh_token",
    refresh_token = refresh_token,
    scope = scope,
    !!!token_params
  )
  # Use [[ to avoid partial matching
  out$refresh_token <- out[["refresh_token"]] %||% refresh_token
  out
}
```

This change ensures we're explicitly checking for the exact name `refresh_token` without any partial matching behavior, resolving the warning that was occurring.

```
pipe <- tibble::tribble(
          ~referral_key, ~appointment_key,        ~result,
            "OP3349021", "4289||10410||1", "4289T10410A1",
            "OP3359764", "4289||10410||2", "4289T10410A2"
          )
pipe
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>   referral_key appointment_key result      
#>   <chr>        <chr>           <chr>       
#> 1 OP3349021    4289||10410||1  4289T10410A1

```

How can I do this with the tidyverse?
samples.target:
Call `str_replace()` twice, once for the first pair of pipes and once for the second:

```
library(tidyverse)

# replace pipes
pipe <- pipe |> 
  mutate(
    # first instance of ||
    appointment_key = str_replace(
      string = appointment_key,
      pattern = '\\|\\|',
      replacement = 'T'
    ),
    # second instance of ||
    appointment_key = str_replace(
      string = appointment_key,
      pattern = '\\|\\|',
      replacement = 'A'
    ),
    # optional: test for equivalence
    equivalent = appointment_key == result
  )
```

Notably, `str_replace()` should be called twice, in order. The solution should not use `str_replace_all()`. Using `||` for the `pattern` is fine as long as `fixed = TRUE`. A correct solution can either assign to `appointment_key` or `result`.

content.text:
# Replacing Pipes with "T" and "A" in the tidyverse

You can replace the pipes (`||`) in the `appointment_key` column with "T" and "A" using the `stringr` package from the tidyverse, specifically with `str_replace_all()`.

Here's how to do it:

```r
library(tidyverse)

pipe <- tibble::tribble(
  ~referral_key, ~appointment_key,        ~result,
  "OP3349021", "4289||10410||1", "4289T10410A1",
  "OP3359764", "4289||10410||2", "4289T10410A2"
)

# Create a new column with the replacement
pipe %>%
  mutate(new_result = str_replace_all(appointment_key, 
                                     pattern = "\\|\\|", 
                                     replacement = c("||" = "T", "||" = "A")))
```

However, the above approach won't work correctly because `str_replace_all()` doesn't handle sequential replacements with different values. Instead, we need a different approach:

```r
pipe %>%
  mutate(new_result = appointment_key %>%
           # Replace first occurrence with "T"
           str_replace("\\|\\|", "T") %>%
           # Replace second occurrence with "A"
           str_replace("\\|\\|", "A"))
```

Alternatively, if you have a fixed format where you know each string has exactly two `||` occurrences:

```r
pipe %>%
  mutate(new_result = gsub("(\\d+)\\|\\|(\\d+)\\|\\|(\\d+)", "\\1T\\2A\\3", appointment_key))
```

This uses a regular expression to capture the numbers between the pipes and reconstruct the string with "T" and "A" instead.

content.text:
# Replacing Pipes with "T" and "A" using Tidyverse

You can achieve this transformation using `stringr::str_replace_all()` within a `dplyr::mutate()` call. Here's how to do it:

```r
library(tidyverse)

pipe <- tibble::tribble(
  ~referral_key, ~appointment_key, ~result,
  "OP3349021", "4289||10410||1", "4289T10410A1",
  "OP3359764", "4289||10410||2", "4289T10410A2"
)

# Create a new column with the replaced values
pipe_transformed <- pipe %>%
  mutate(transformed = str_replace_all(appointment_key, 
                                       pattern = "\\|\\|", 
                                       replacement = function(x) {
                                         if(str_count(appointment_key, "\\|\\|") == 2 && 
                                            x == substr(appointment_key, 5, 6)) {
                                           return("T")
                                         } else {
                                           return("A")
                                         }
                                       }))

# Simpler approach using positional replacement
pipe_transformed <- pipe %>%
  mutate(transformed = str_replace_all(appointment_key, 
                                       c("^(\\d+)\\|\\|(\\d+)\\|\\|(\\d+)$" = "\\1T\\2A\\3")))

# Check if the transformation matches the expected result
pipe_transformed %>%
  mutate(matches = transformed == result)
```

The second approach is more straightforward and reliable. It:

1. Uses a regex pattern to capture three groups of digits separated by `||`
2. Replaces them with the first group, followed by "T", followed by the second group, followed by "A", followed by the third group
